ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Office Hours, French table, and peer tutoring.
Occasional film watching.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: French grammar; skills in reading french literature

My French writing skills very much improved throughout the semester and my ability to work my way through describing more complex ideas about gender and class did improve (even if I was still stumbling through).
I learned a lot about French society in different eras of history.
I reviewed many topics in French grammar (various verb tenses, pronouns, etc) and learned many new words. I also learned about French culture, literature, and film.
Improved fluency in French, practice composing essays in French, conversational skills, grammar practice.
This course heavily focuses on grammar and vocabulary, so it was a really good review. Oral elements exist, but this course is definitely more geared towards reading and writing.

You greatly develop your french speaking skills, enrich your vocabulary and refine your command of different grammar formations as well as learn about different aspects of french culture and politics through literature, film, art, and music.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It would be nice to have more diversity in material (other french-speaking countries)

Strengths: You learn a lot of vocab! While the focus on grammar is pretty challenging, it is definitely useful and I feel like I gained a better grasp on the French language.

Weaknesses: This course is embarrassingly euro-centric. For a language that has been imposed on so many different people around the world, it was so upsetting to see that the readings and other media that we engaged with were both outdated and focused on white (European) narratives. There was only one text that focused on non-white people and that took place after 1970. There are so many French writers of African and Asian decent that easily could have been incorporated into the curriculum to teach similar (if not more dynamic) lessons than the ones this course focused on.
I wish we would have learned more about modern France and other francophone countries, rather than only focusing on historical pieces.

A strength of this course is the course book/textbook, which had all the vocabulary lists and grammatical information and was structured well. A weakness of this course is that it is structured so that the students primarily learn the grammar by themselves, and are expected to understand and utilize it in class.

The small class size improved conversation. I appreciated the varied works we studied, from film to short story to literature. I wish that the reading/watching list had been more representative of the diversity of the Francophone world as we focused mainly on European stories.

The books you have to read are pretty interesting and discussing or writing about them can be fun. The grammar exercises are a bit excessive and probably should be cut down to reinforce certain rules or exceptions. The videos and movies are pretty fun to watch too.
this course does an excellent job of building vocab, but there could have been more in class attention given to ensuring that students understood the grammar formations they review for homework

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class was adapted well

I'm not sure of how the class was structured before, but adaptations to working on zoom seemed to be very little if at all there. Assignments and expectations seemed to not budge with different circumstances.
Overall I think that this course was conducted well online -- we were able to effectively go over vocab, grammar, readings, and everyone participated.
generally the class offers as covid-friendly a model as any other remote learning class format, but the spacing of assignments at times felt inconsiderate, specifically during finals season.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It's a fun, relatively easy way to get an L5 language credit.
I would recommend this course if you want to improve in French and solidify your understanding of grammar rules for sure.

I would recommend this course to someone if they wanted to improve their French vocab and grammar as well as writing and oral skills. The work is very self-motivated, so in order to improve, a student would really need to do every single assignment, read all the books, and watch all the films.

I would recommend this course if the student wants to sure up their grammar skills. They should already be proficient in French as the course does not allow much time for re-learning grammar. The student should expect each of the three exams to cover a lot, perhaps too much material. The inclusion of short grammar quizzes could help alleviate some of this pressure.
if you want to better your french and build your speaking skills, I would definitely recommend this course.
